text: I really enjoy things at the intersection of hilarious and useful. You kind of need both. And hilarious just because you should have fun in life. We should be working on things that are fun and interesting. Also, candidly, if we're being more honest about it's very hard to cut through the noise these days. So you need humor is a great way to cut through it, but humor just for the sake of being funny is not that useful.
speaker: Sam Lessin
context: Lenny asks Sam why he decided to focus on teaching proper etiquette and why people should pay attention to this topic. Sam explains his philosophy for choosing projects - he looks for things that are both entertaining and practically valuable. He believes that in today's noisy information environment, humor is essential for getting people's attention, but it must be paired with genuine utility to have lasting impact.
text_ko: 저는 웃기면서도 쓸모 있는 것들, 그 교차점에 있는 걸 정말 좋아해요. 둘 다 필요하거든요. 웃긴 건 그냥 인생은 즐거워야 하니까요. 우리는 재미있고 흥미로운 일을 해야 해요. 그리고 솔직히 말하면 요즘은 잡음 속에서 눈에 띄기가 정말 힘들어요 (cut through the noise). 그래서 유머는 그걸 뚫고 나가는 좋은 방법이에요. 다만 웃기기만 한 유머는 별로 쓸모가 없어요.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢那种既搞笑又实用的东西，这两样缺一不可。搞笑是因为生活就应该有乐趣嘛，我们做的事情应该既好玩又有意思。另外，说实话，现在信息太多太杂了，想要突出重围真的很难。幽默是个很好的突破方式，但如果只是为了搞笑而搞笑，那就没什么用了。
text_es: Me encanta trabajar en cosas que sean divertidas y útiles a la vez. Necesitas las dos cosas. Lo divertido porque hay que disfrutar la vida, ¿no? Deberíamos estar trabajando en proyectos que nos emocionen y nos parezcan interesantes. Y siendo honestos, hoy en día es súper difícil destacar entre tanto ruido. El humor es una manera genial de lograrlo, pero hacer chistes nada más por hacerlos no sirve de mucho.
key_sentence: Humor cuts through the noise but must be useful, not just funny.

text: Understanding how to meet people, where they're at, build trust, mirror kind of expected behaviors. These are all tools. And so that's the deep truth. The shallow truth is it's kind of funny to teach Silicon Valley people etiquette. The whole narrative for so long has been, none of this matters, just focus on your product.
speaker: Sam Lessin
context: Sam continues explaining why etiquette matters for founders in 2025. He argues that as technology becomes more central to business and people worry about job displacement, understanding social skills becomes crucial for building trust with partners and customers. He contrasts the 'deep truth' (etiquette genuinely matters for business success) with the 'shallow truth' (it's amusing to teach etiquette to tech people who've traditionally dismissed social conventions).
text_ko: 사람들을 어떻게 만나고, 그들이 지금 어떤 상황인지 파악하고, 신뢰를 쌓고, 기대되는 행동을 맞춰 보여주는 법을 아는 것 — 이 모든 게 도구예요. 그래서 그게 진짜 핵심이에요. 반면 피상적인 진실은 실리콘밸리 사람들에게 에티켓(etiquette)을 가르치는 게 좀 웃기다는 거예요. 오랫동안 이어져 온 이야기 흐름은 '이런 건 중요하지 않으니 그냥 제품(product)에만 집중해라'였죠.
text_zh: 要懂得怎么跟人打交道，了解别人的想法，建立信任，做一些大家期望看到的行为。这些都是工具嘛。这就是深层的道理。表面上看，教硅谷那些人礼仪挺有意思的。因为长期以来他们的观念就是，这些东西都不重要，专心做好产品就行了。
text_es: Entender cómo conectar con la gente donde están, generar confianza, reflejar las conductas que esperan. Todo eso son herramientas. Y esa es la verdad profunda. La verdad superficial es que tiene su gracia enseñarle protocolo a la gente de Silicon Valley. Durante mucho tiempo la narrativa ha sido: nada de esto importa, solo enfócate en tu producto.
key_sentence: Meeting people where they're at builds trust and mirrors expected behaviors.

text: You're at the Kleiner Perkins holiday party. You have all the venture capitalists in the world and all the CEOs. You're at your first company, you're young, maybe you're from a different country. You're like, 'Oh my God, this is my shot. I have all these people I need to talk to and I need to convince this person of that and make this connection.' It becomes very transactional. If you show up like a little energizer bunny, you're going to scare one off.
speaker: Sam Lessin
context: Sam describes a scenario where a young founder attends a high-profile networking event filled with important investors and executives. He explains how the pressure and excitement can cause someone to approach networking in the wrong way - being overly eager and transactional rather than building genuine relationships. The 'energizer bunny' reference describes someone who is hyperactive and overwhelming in social situations.
text_ko: 클라이너 퍼킨스(Kleiner Perkins) 홀리데이 파티에 와 있다고 생각해 보세요. 온갖 벤처 투자자들(venture capitalists)과 수많은 CEO들이 모여 있어요. 당신은 첫 직장에서 일하는 젊은 사람일 수도 있고, 어쩌면 외국에서 온 사람일 수도 있죠. ‘세상에, 이게 내 기회야. 이 사람들 다 만나서 누구는 설득하고, 누구랑은 연결을 만들어야 해’라고 생각하며 너무 계산적이고 거래적(transactional)이 돼 버려요. 에너자이저 토끼처럼(energizer bunny) 지나치게 활기차게 굴면 사람 하나쯤은 질려서 떠나요.
text_zh: 你在凯鹏华盈(Kleiner Perkins)的年会上，满场都是全世界的风投(VC)和CEO。你刚创业，年纪轻，可能还是外国人。你心里想着："天哪，这是我的机会啊！这些人我都得聊聊，得说服这个，还得搭上那条线。" 结果就变得特别功利。如果你像个小马达似的到处蹦跶，肯定会把人给吓跑的。
text_es: Estás en la fiesta navideña de Kleiner Perkins. Tienes ahí a todos los capitalistas de riesgo del mundo y a todos los CEOs. Es tu primera empresa, eres joven, tal vez eres de otro país. Y piensas: "Dios mío, esta es mi oportunidad. Tengo que hablar con toda esta gente, necesito convencer a este de aquello y hacer tal conexión." Se vuelve algo muy calculado, muy transaccional. Si llegas como un conejito de Energizer súper intenso, vas a espantar a más de uno.
key_sentence: Being a little energizer bunny can scare one off in transactional settings.

text: I think understanding how to show up, take a beat, come in with a mindset, not of scarcity, but of abundance, understand how to give more than you take, understand how to build a relationship, not collect business cards. These are things that actually serve you massively well.
speaker: Sam Lessin
context: Sam continues his advice about networking events, contrasting the wrong approach with the right one. Instead of desperately trying to extract value from every interaction, he advocates for an abundance mindset - believing there will be more opportunities and focusing on building genuine relationships rather than just gathering contacts. 'Take a beat' means to pause and calm yourself before entering a social situation.
text_ko: 어떻게 나타나서 잠깐 멈춰서, 결핍(scarcity)이 아니라 풍요(abundance)의 마음가짐으로 임하는지, 받는 것보다 더 많이 주는 법, 명함을 수집하는 게 아니라 관계를 쌓는 법을 아는 것—이런 것들이 실제로 엄청난 도움이 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得关键是要懂得怎么出现，先冷静一下，带着一种心态进场——不是那种稀缺思维，而是富足思维，要懂得多付出少索取，要懂得真正去建立关系，而不是光收集名片。这些东西其实对你帮助特别大。
text_es: Creo que entender cómo presentarte, tomarte un momento para respirar, llegar con una mentalidad no de escasez, sino de abundancia, saber cómo dar más de lo que recibes, entender cómo construir relaciones de verdad, no solo coleccionar tarjetas de presentación. Estas son cosas que realmente te van a servir muchísimo.
key_sentence: Adopt an abundance mindset to give more than you take and build relationships.

text: I'd also say that, look, this goes back to technical differentiation where things are at. It is true that if you bring manna from heaven, you invent something that is literally the next Google or whatever out of pure thought that sometimes none of this stuff matters, that's it. It's literally like that happens. It happens very, very rarely, but it does happen.
speaker: Sam Lessin
context: Lenny asks whether someone can be successful without knowing etiquette rules, and Sam acknowledges this is possible in rare cases. He uses the biblical reference 'manna from heaven' (meaning an unexpected gift or blessing) to describe startups that create something so revolutionary that social skills become irrelevant. However, he emphasizes this applies to very few companies - those that build truly groundbreaking products like Google.
text_ko: 또 한 가지 말하자면, 이건 결국 기술적 차별화(technical differentiation)가 어디에 있느냐로 되돌아가요. 사실 만약 하늘에서 기적처럼 떨어져서 순수한 생각만으로 문자 그대로 다음 구글(Google)을 만들어낸다면, 그럴 때는 이 모든 게 아무래도 상관없어져요. 실제로 그런 일이 일어나기도 해요. 아주, 아주 드물게 일어나긴 하지만요.
text_zh: 我还想说，你看，这又回到了技术差异化的问题上。确实是这样，如果你真的能带来天赐良机，纯粹靠想法就发明出下一个谷歌那样的东西，那有时候这些都不重要了，就是这么回事。真的就是这样。这种情况非常非常少见，但确实会发生。
text_es: Yo también diría que, mira, esto vuelve a la diferenciación técnica y dónde están las cosas. Es cierto que si traes el maná del cielo, si inventas algo que sea literalmente el próximo Google o lo que sea, salido de la pura imaginación, a veces nada de esto importa, punto. Así de simple. Pasa muy, muy rara vez, pero sí pasa.
key_sentence: Manna from heaven inventions happen rarely, but they can change everything.

text: You kind of want to show up with the self-confidence and the calm of abundance, being like, 'This is not going to be my only opportunity. This is an opportunity. I'm excited to be here. I'm engaged. This is part of the story. This is not the entire story.'
speaker: Sam Lessin
context: Sam explains how to mentally approach important networking opportunities or meetings. Rather than treating each interaction as a make-or-break moment (like the Eminem song lyric 'one shot, one opportunity'), he advises projecting confidence that comes from believing you'll have future chances. This abundance mindset helps you stay calm and build better relationships because you're not desperately trying to extract maximum value from every single interaction.
vocabulary_highlights: part of the story, not the entire story
text_ko: 여유로운 자신감과 차분함으로 나타나면 좋아요. '이게 내 유일한 기회는 아니에요. 그냥 하나의 기회고, 여기 와서 기쁘고 적극적으로 참여하고 있어요. 이건 이야기의 한 부분일 뿐 전부는 아니에요.'
text_zh: 你要带着那种自信和从容的心态出现，就像——这不是我唯一的机会，这只是其中一个机会。我很兴奋能在这里，我很投入。这只是故事的一部分，不是全部。
text_es: Quieres presentarte con esa confianza en ti mismo y esa tranquilidad de quien tiene opciones, con esa actitud de 'Esta no va a ser mi única oportunidad. Es una oportunidad más. Me emociona estar aquí. Estoy comprometido. Esto es parte de la historia, no toda la historia.'
key_sentence: Show up with the calm of abundance; this is part of the story.

text: The reality is etiquette ironically matters a lot. There is a deep truth to this. Especially when you're asking people to trust you with their data, trust you with their business. And when technology is no longer some cute sideshow, but it's a major deal, people are worried about losing their jobs.
speaker: Sam Lessin
context: Sam makes his core argument for why etiquette has become crucial for modern founders and tech professionals. As technology has moved from being a niche interest to something that affects everyone's livelihood, the stakes have gotten much higher. When you're asking people to trust you with sensitive business data or critical systems, your social presentation and trustworthiness become essential factors in their decision-making process.
text_ko: 사실 아이러니하게도 에티켓이 꽤 중요해요. 그 말엔 깊은 진실이 담겨 있어요. 특히 사람들에게 자신의 데이터(data)나 비즈니스(business)를 믿고 맡겨 달라고 할 때는 더 그렇죠. 그리고 기술(technology)이 더 이상 단순한 볼거리나 부수적인 것이 아니라 핵심 사안이 되면, 사람들은 일자리를 잃을까 봐 걱정해요.
text_zh: 现实情况是，礼貌礼节这些东西，说起来挺讽刺的，其实特别重要。这里面有很深层的道理。特别是当你要别人把数据交给你，把生意托付给你的时候。而且现在技术已经不是什么好玩的小把戏了，而是大事情，大家都担心会丢饭碗。
text_es: La realidad es que, irónicamente, la etiqueta importa muchísimo. En esto hay una verdad muy profunda. Sobre todo cuando les estás pidiendo a las personas que confíen en ti con sus datos, que confíen en ti con su negocio. Y cuando la tecnología ya no es algo simpático de segundo plano, sino que es algo serio de verdad, la gente está preocupada por perder su trabajo.
key_sentence: Etiquette ironically matters a lot, especially when asking for trust with data.
